page.title: 05 SIT & GEO PT3.LOCAL HIST 1
page.content:
Geological ages ago the Thames bed was probably something over a hundred feet higher than at the present time and the river flowed over this terrain from what is now Pangbourne direct to Henley, where it was joined by the Loddon which to-day enters at Wargrave.
*************** {WELLS} *************** It may be inferred therefore that wells were both important to the community and costly to dig, because they had necessarily to be deep. Dunsden Well, which has now been sealed and provided with a canopy to protect the remains of the original winding gear made by the firm of Wilder, was dug in 1878 to a depth of one hundred and fifty feet,"at the expense of Susanna Caroline Palmer and Isobella Crawshay for the inhabitants of Dunsden for ever", to quote the commemorative tablet.
